title: Do teachers talk about their students at home? - Quora

response.answer_text: When I was a student teacher, I talked about little things with my parents that the kids did and said. Like “Joe wrote this really beautiful piece about why he prefers bush walks to beach walks today! He really convinced me!” or “You know what Kayla did when she saw me? She hugged me and said welcome back. Isn’t that sweet?” or “I found out today that Jack hates pizza! He’s like the only kid who chose pasta over pizza in the “this or that” sheet I gave them for argument writing.” or “I feel so terrible about my Maori accent. Kamaia’s accent is so good - she could probably teach Maori better than I could.” or “Reuben told me today that all the other kids are mean to him. I haven’t seen anything, but the way he describes it is how I used to think, so I understand why he believes it” or “I really admire the way Chloe acted today. She’s super mature for seven.” So yeah, I do talk about the kids. I figure that my parents don’t know them, will never know them and won’t tell anyone, so it’s all right to tell them. They won’t remember it. But all those things I just said - they’re all true. Joe is a talented writer, Kayla is sweet, Jack hates pizza, Kamaia’s Maori herself and puts me to shame with my accent, I really get where Reuben’s coming from, and Chloe is the most mature kid I’ve ever met, yet she’s still as playful and girly as any child. Of course, this is from two or three years ago, but I still miss those kids, and I hope they’re doing okay now.

Yes. When I was in teaching, students were a regular topic: in staff rooms, at home, in coffee shops, etc. Most teachers are very careful about revealing personal details (there are, after all, legal restrictions about revealing certain kinds of information about students). But talking about “this one student” or “this one kid” was very common. It should go without saying that the comments were not always negative. Everyone wants to let off steam at home, but the teachers I knew generally were happier to discuss kids who were doing well, or how to help kids who were struggling (the exception to this rule was in the staff room…most staff room conversations seemed to be nothing but bitch fests, probably the reason I didn’t spend much time there).

I am a primary school teacher and so is my husband. We talk about the kids all the time after coming home. All the funny incidents, their talents, good and bad everything. One example… Yesterday when he was indulging students in some activity with alphabet which can stick to a board with the help of a magnet… a 3rd class boy told him to take the letter N and stick it to his bike because his name starts with N. And out of the blue a girl of same class asks him to stick ‘S’ instead of N. When he asked why.. she told him that she heard him talking in the phone repeatedly calling the name ‘soundharya’. And she knows that it's his wife's name😅.. my husband is shocked. He told me this when he came home. And this is just one small incident. I can tell u many such incidents.. It's a boon to work with kids. They are such lovely creatures. We both feel blessed for that. And when we share each others kids things we feel happy and we also give suggestions to each other to improve ourselves in our work. Thanku :-)

It's pretty Common to talk about your work at home with your spouse. As we both are in teaching field we have lot of stories to tell everyday. I know many students of my husband's college and I admire the way he narrates the daily incidents. He also knows my student stories. Some are funny, some scary, some sad. we talk about toppers, slow learners, mischievous, decent and hardworking students. One incident.. “You know today a parent came and slapped his daughter in front of me. I stopped him, otherwise he would have killed her..” “But what made him slap his daughter?” “She went with one of her classmate to a movie bunking college” “Oh, they must have been tensed” “Yes, raising kids now days has become a challenge” Matter ends there. Next day… “Did that girl come to college?” “No, her father wants to change her college” So this is our routine conversation.

Yes. It’s normal for adults to talk with their spouses in the evening about what they did all day. For teachers, you can’t really talk about your work day without talking about students. My wife has gotten to “know” some of my students really well over the years, even though she’s never met them. I’ve also gotten to “know” some of her coworkers over the years, even though I’ve never met them, either.

upvoters.user_id: Jack Davies（デイビースジャック）

response.answer_text: Yes. I used to share the stories of my students with my family. Daily at the time of dinner I used to narrate everything that happened at school that day. Mostly about the naughtiness of the students who mostly creates fun in the classroom, students who were punished that day, how the other teachers treat the weak students what sort of comments they pass in the staffroom!! and health issues of some students. My mother was so concerned about such students and so regularly enquires about their condition. Some used to share their struggles and financial condition. Listening to their pain makes me depressed so to come out of it I share those with my family which releases some stress from me !

Yes, we ever talk about our each student because they are our life and we are born to serve them, and to make them disciplined with the help of our core knowledge experience and skills we have in our minds’ thoughts and even in our mental abilities approach. We ever remain in thinking for whole the day and use to think over all those strategies and possible teaching methodological ways through which we could help them in recover their studies deficiencies and enable them to become more confident to face the tomorrow complex world challenges successfully and in an awesome ways strategies and stood exemplary for others. Its our motto, our life mission and aim too to see them on the high peak point and make them successful in their future career professional life.

Of course they do, at home, in the staff room, with friends, colleagues, relatives etc so if you’re a student, try not to stand out, or at least try to stand out in a good way. If you’re a troublemaker, be aware that a lot of people would know not necessarily who you are, but certainly what you did (or didn’t do), and the more you stand out, the more people might know what you did.
Haha! Well, depends ! How well you do in class. How well mannered you are and or how naughty you are. Naughty student are always been discussed at their teachers’ homes. Because, they are naughty.
